Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Lightweight Self-sensing Robotic End Effectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop silent assistive robotic arms and end-tools for new robotic applications. The lightweight and dexterous tools – on the end of an agile robotic arm – will be able to perform intricate tasks such as cutting, pinching, and grasping for uses as diverse as panning/tilting cameras, to assembly tasks, to picking soft fruits and berries. Beyond improved cost and energy efficiency, these new devices will enable new personal robot applications. In addition, due to their simplicity and significantly lower weight and size, the proposed products will consume fewer natural resources than their current counterparts and can be more easily recycled due to the smaller number of components, ultimately enabling greater use of assistive robotic devices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will explore the potential of using using Shape Memory (SM) and Superelastic (SE) nitinol wires instead of motors. SM/SE wires are alloys of Nickel and Titanium that contract aggressively when heated with electrical current, producing large forces and modest stroke; they can enable lighter, more efficient robotic joints and tools to perform a variety of human tasks. The technical objectives are to design a lightweight, agile, and silent robotic arm and end effectors utilizing SM and SE nitinol wires to both drive and sense position and forces. The end effectors will be a pincher/gripper and a cutter. The arm and end tools will be designed for tasks and loads typically performed by human hands, creating new tools for applications and loads between delicate surgeries and larger-scale industrial usage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phase 1 NSF SBIR Project Outcomes Report

Lightweight Self-sensing Robotic End Effectors | Award # 1938550

Dr. Mark A. Gummin, Miga Technologies, LLC

 

Shape Memory Alloys (SMAs) are wires made from Nickel and Titanium (known as Nitinol) that contract aggressively when heated with electrical current.  SMA wires as thin as a few strands of hair can be used to create highly compact and lightweight electronic actuators – devices that produce motion. An SMA wire actuator roughly the size and weight of a folded credit card, for example, can provide the movement to unlock an automotive glovebox, offering significant weight- and space- savings over existing actuators. In addition, actuators made from SMA wires are totally silent – adding further to their appeal. 

Another interesting property of Nitinol is known as Superelasticity.  Superelastic (SE) Nitinol wires can be stretched or bent much farther than any other metal, without damaging the wire. This would allow a hair-thin SE wire to be used as a simple extension spring in very compact mechanical devices.  At the same time, the electrical resistance of an SE wire increases when it is stretched, allowing SE wires to also be used as a stretch or position sensor. Combining those properties with SMA wires, one can produce compact, lightweight, self-sensing mechanisms. 

SMA wire actuators are a very new technology that is slowly being introduced into automotive, industrial, and consumer applications, but they are not yet used for many robotic applications. The goal of this NSF phase 1 project was to study a variety of SM and SE Nitinol alloys to determine which ones are most appropriate for use in robotic arms and end effectors, and to demonstrate that we could produce a robotic arm joint and end effector made entirely with Nitinol wires, with no other motors required. 

What is an end effector?  It is the tool on the end of a robotic arm that performs tasks such as gripping or cutting. As robots are increasingly being used to perform repetitive tasks throughout industry, there is also an increasing need for new end tools that are suited to those tasks. Why are lightweight end effectors important?  Because the less weight there is at the end of a robotic arm, the less energy required to move the arm. Lightweight, self-sensing end effectors: energy efficient solutions for tomorrows robotic applications. 

One of the more interesting results from our study is the temperature behavior of SE wires. When implemented as a position-sensing extension spring, we found that if the temperature of the SE wire is increased (by heating with a small electrical current, for example), the spring becomes stronger and stronger… pulling harder and harder as the temperature rises. This is a ‘variable stiffness’ spring – one whose stiffness can be ‘controlled’ electronically.  So a single, hair-thin SE wire implemented as a spring in a mechanical system serves three functions at the same time – a variable-stiffness, self-sensing bias spring – enabling the design of compact, nearly weightless cutters, for example.  The spring, itself, can be used to sense and then to damp out any unwanted oscillation of the mechanism in real time, which has never been done before.

SMA and SE wires are not without their drawbacks, and they are challenging to understand and control, let alone to develop them into products that make the most of their unique qualities. A lot of research must still be done to fully understand their properties, and then to exploit those properties to develop successful products.

During the course of our NSF Phase 1 program, we developed processes to apply thin coatings of silicone doped with aluminum powder onto SMA wires, which allows the wires to cool nearly 6 times faster than un-coated SMA wires. This advance would allow a small robotic cutter, for example, to perform 2 operations per second: sufficient for many laboratory or industrial settings.

We also purchased, trained, and characterized many different SM and SE alloy wires. Along with engineers at Toyota Motor Engineering & Manufacturing North America, Inc., we then designed, built, and tested several generations of robotic arm joints and both pincher/gripper and cutter end tools using the SMA and SE wires that we developed and studied during the program.  Both the robotic arms, and the end tools successfully demonstrated the potential of using SM and SE wires (without the use of any other motors) for compact, lightweight robotic applications.

Modified by: Mark A Gummin
